column1: What is a floating-rate note (FRN)?
column2: A bond whose coupon resets periodically based on a market reference rate (MRR) plus a fixed quoted margin.  [oai_citation:0‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the coupon formula for an FRN?
column2: Coupon rate = market reference rate + quoted margin.  [oai_citation:1‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the market reference rate (MRR)?
column2: A benchmark short-term rate used to set FRN coupons
column3: such as LIBOR or Euribor.  [oai_citation:2‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the quoted margin (QM)?
column2: The fixed spread added to the reference rate to determine the FRN’s coupon.  [oai_citation:3‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why are FRNs usually issued at par?
column2: Because at issuance the quoted margin equals the required margin
column3: so price equals par.  [oai_citation:4‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What happens to an FRN’s price if credit risk increases?
column2: Required margin rises above quoted margin
column3: making the coupon too low → FRN trades at a discount.  [oai_citation:5‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What happens when required margin is lower than the quoted margin?
column2: The FRN's coupon is generous
column3: so it trades at a premium.  [oai_citation:6‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the discount margin (DM)?
column2: The margin investors currently require over the reference rate to price the FRN.  [oai_citation:7‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: At issuance
column2: how are QM and DM related?
column4: so the FRN is priced at par.  [oai_citation:8‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: If DM > QM
column2: where does the FRN trade?
column3: Below par (at a discount).  [oai_citation:9‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: If DM < QM
column2: where does the FRN trade?
column3: Above par (at a premium).  [oai_citation:10‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What determines an FRN’s price after issuance?
column2: How the required margin (DM) changes relative to the fixed quoted margin (QM).  [oai_citation:11‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why do FRNs have low interest rate risk?
column2: Because the coupon frequently adjusts to market rates
column3: keeping price close to par.  [oai_citation:12‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What do FRN investors primarily worry about?
column2: Changes in the issuer’s credit risk reflected in the discount margin.  [oai_citation:13‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the role of the reference rate in FRNs?
column2: It sets the floating part of the coupon each reset period.  [oai_citation:14‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the holding period yield (HPY)?
column2: The return earned over the actual days the investor holds the instrument.  [oai_citation:15‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is an add-on yield?
column2: A money-market yield quoted as interest paid on the invested amount
column3: annualized.  [oai_citation:16‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: For add-on yields
column2: how is quoted rate defined?
column3: Quoted add-on yield = HPY × (year basis / days).  [oai_citation:17‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What year conventions are used for add-on yields?
column2: Either 365-day year or 360-day year depending on the instrument.  [oai_citation:18‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you compute HPY from a 365-day add-on yield?
column2: HPY = quoted yield × days / 365.  [oai_citation:19‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you compute HPY from a 360-day add-on yield?
column2: HPY = quoted yield × days / 360.  [oai_citation:20‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is a discount yield?
column2: A T-bill style quote based on the annualized discount from face value using a 360-day year.  [oai_citation:21‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How is the quoted discount yield computed?
column2: Quoted discount yield = discount × 360 / days.  [oai_citation:22‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you compute actual discount?
column2: Actual discount = (face value − price) ÷ face value.  [oai_citation:23‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why is HPY different from the discount yield?
column2: Discount yield is based on face value
column3: while HPY is based on the actual price paid.  [oai_citation:24‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is bond-equivalent yield (BEY)?
column2: An add-on yield annualized on a 365-day basis so it can be compared with bond YTMs.  [oai_citation:25‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why is BEY used?
column2: To standardize different yield quoting conventions into one comparable format.  [oai_citation:26‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you convert a 365-day add-on yield to BEY?
column2: No conversion needed—the yield already equals BEY.  [oai_citation:27‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you convert a 360-day add-on yield to BEY?
column2: BEY = add-on × 365 / 360.  [oai_citation:28‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you compute BEY from a discount yield?
column2: Recover price → compute HPY → annualize HPY on 365-day basis.  [oai_citation:29‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What type of instruments use discount yields?
column2: Treasury bills and other pure-discount securities.  [oai_citation:30‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What type of instruments use add-on yields?
column2: Bank CDs
column4: and most short-term deposits.  [oai_citation:31‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why can discount yields be misleading?
column2: They understate the true return because they are based on face value
column3: not actual price.  [oai_citation:32‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What does a higher discount margin imply?
column2: Higher required compensation for credit and liquidity risk.  [oai_citation:33‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why does an FRN priced at par imply QM = DM?
column2: Because the coupon payments exactly match the required yield at that margin.  [oai_citation:34‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why does an FRN priced at a discount imply QM < DM?
column2: Market now demands a higher spread than the bond pays.  [oai_citation:35‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why does an FRN priced at a premium imply QM > DM?
column2: The bond pays more spread than the market currently requires.  [oai_citation:36‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How is FRN price sensitivity compared to fixed-rate bonds?
column2: Much lower because coupons reset frequently.  [oai_citation:37‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What causes FRN price volatility?
column2: Changes in the discount margin (credit risk)
column3: not changes in the reference rate.  [oai_citation:38‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why is the reference rate reset crucial?
column2: It keeps coupon payments aligned with current market conditions.  [oai_citation:39‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the usual maturity range for money-market instruments?
column2: Less than one year.  [oai_citation:40‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How does HPY relate to BEY?
column2: BEY is the annualized version of HPY on a 365-day basis.  [oai_citation:41‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: How do you compute T-bill price from discount yield?
column2: Price = face × (1 − actual discount).  [oai_citation:42‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: If you know HPY and days to maturity
column2: how do you compute an add-on quoted yield?
column3: Quoted yield = HPY × (year basis / days).  [oai_citation:43‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What happens to discount yield when days increase?
column2: For the same HPY
column3: discount yield decreases because it's annualized over more days.  [oai_citation:44‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why are 360-day conventions used?
column2: Historical banking practice for money-market calculations.  [oai_citation:45‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: Why are 365-day conventions used?
column2: To align yields with standard bond-equivalent quoting formats.  [oai_citation:46‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)

column1: What is the purpose of standardizing yields?
column2: To allow fair comparison across instruments with different quoting norms.  [oai_citation:47‡54 Yield Measures for Floating Rate Notes.pdf](sediment://file_00000000c8a471f4b89f7519d8c27c90)
